title: Man ‘banned’ from takeaways because of his weight loses 20st
text:
Darren McClintock is literally half the person he was 12 months ago after losing 20st (Picture: Mike Hind/SWNS)

An obese man who was ‘banned’ from his favourite takeaways after being told he was eating himself to death has dropped 20st in less than a year.

Darren ‘Dibsy’ McClintock, 28, called on gym boss Mike Hind, 36, after doctors warned him he would die if he didn’t start leading a healthier lifestyle.

He gave up fizzy drinks, swapped fast food for a more controlled diet and embarked on a rigorous training regime that saw him burn up to 3,000 calories per day.

Mike also drafted posters to deliver to all his new client’s local takeaways saying: ‘Save Dibsy. Obesity is killing him. Do not serve this man.’

Now, 12 months later and one week shy of his target date, Dibsy, from Middlesbrough, has beaten his aim of losing 20st within a year.

Dibsy embarked on the epic weight loss journey last October after doctors warned he was ‘eating himself to death’ (Picture: Mike Hind/SWNS)

One of Mike’s first steps was to draft this poster warning Dibsy’s favourite takeaway’s to stop serving him (Picture: Mike Hind/SWNS)

This time last year Dibsy couldn’t walk up the stairs, wear a seat belt, fit in the bath or travel on public transport (Picture: Mike Hind/SWNS)

Since turning his life around he’s competed in the Great North Run, fought in a charity boxing match and climbed Ben Nevis (Picture: SWNS)

Dibsy’s fitness regime saw him burn 3,000 calories a day (Picture: SWNS)

‘How can you put into words what has happened?’ Mike said. ‘Twelve months ago Dibsy was told he was going to die if he didn’t lose weight.’

He added: ‘When I first met him, I couldn’t believe it. He could hardly walk a flight of stairs. He walked up the stairs to my office and he was screaming in pain because he wasn’t used to it.’

Since beginning his weight loss journey Dibsy has won a charity boxing match, completed the Great North Run and found himself a girlfriend.

And trainer Mike said it was all down to Dibsy’s hard work.

‘I cannot fault Dibsy,’ he added. ‘He did everything I asked of him and did everything that was expected.’

During an appearance on This Morning earlier this year Dibsy said the fitness regime had been ‘difficult’, but added he was ‘enjoying it’.

‘The training is hard. I lay in bed at night and think it’s going to be hard tomorrow, but I know I’ve got to do it,’ he said.

Dibsy at the Masbody Gym in Middlesborough (Picture: SWNS)

Among his many achievements over the last year is finding himself a girlfriend (Picture: SWNS)

Dibsy was due to be officially weighed next week in front of TV crews, but Mike decided to do it early and was astonished at the result.

He now hopes to raise enough money for an operation to remove his excess skin, left behind by the dramatic weight loss.

‘We’ve been consulting with plastic surgeons but he is healthy enough to go into an operation and there will be more news on that soon,’ Mike said.

‘He’s now got a girlfriend and he’s very happy, he met someone on his journey.

‘He’s not just saved his life, he’s changed it for the better.’
